summary: The study reports the use of enzymes for regioselective acylation of castanospermine to synthesize various esters. Subtilisin and lipases from different sources exhibit distinct regioselectivities in these reactions.
key_claims: Subtilisin shows a strong preference for acylation at the C6 position.
Lipase from Chromobacterium visciosum is especially active with isolated yields of up to 80%.

process_signals.name: yield
process_signals.context: for the reaction catalyzed by lipase from Chromobacterium visciosum

Enzymatic Synthesis of 6-0-Butyrylcastanospermine and 7-0-Butyrylcastanospermine. Castanospermine, 68 mg (0.36 mmol), was dissolved in 6 mL of warm anhydrous pyridine, followed by addition of I58 mg (0.72 mmol) of (2,2,2-trichloroethyI)butyrate. Then 600 mg of crude porcine pancreatic lipase was added
Then the lipase was removed by filtration, the pyridine evaporated under vacuum, and the product isolated and purified by radial silica gel chromatography using 20% EtOH/ CH2C12 as the eluent

The conditions of the syntheses of di-0-acyl derivatives of castanospermine are described in footnote a to Table 11. Following filtration of the enzyme, the THF was evaporated under vacuum. The remaining residue was subjected to radial silica gel chromatography on a Chromatotron using EtOH/CH2C12 as the eluent

_abstract: Several biologically active esters of castanospermine [( lS,6&7R$R,8aR)-1,6,7,8-tetrahydroxyotahydroindolizine] have been synthesized on a preparative scale in pyridine by using the proteolytic enzyme subtilisin as a catalyst. Under these conditions, subtilisin possesses a high regioselectivity and at the same time a broad substrate specificity and enantioselectivity. This fact makes possible the synthesis of a wide variety of I-0-acyl derivatives via castanospermine esterification. It is possible to regulate the hydrophobicity of the acylating group (acetyl, butyryl, octanoyl)  or to incorporate an aromatic moiety (phenylacetyl) or L and D amino acids (phenylalanyl, L-and D-ahyl). Since 1 -esters of castanospermine are soluble in several organic solvents, they have been employed as intermediates in the preparation of diesters. Porcine pancreatic lipase, lipase from Chromobacterium uiscosum, and subtilisin have been used as catalysts for further enzymatic acylation of 1 -0-acyl derivat
